div.head: ACT I

stage.stage: The hall of EARTH-SPIRIT , Act IV , feebly lighted by an oil lamp on the centre table . Even this is dimmed by a heavy shade . Lulu 's picture is gone from the easel , which still stands by the foot of the stairs . The fire-screen and the chair by the ottoman are gone too . Down left is a small tea-table , with a coffee-pot and a cup of black coffee on it , and an arm-chair next it .

In this chair , deep in cushions , with a plaid shawl over her knees , sits Countess Geschwitz in a tight black dress . Rodrigo , clad as a servant , sits on the ottoman . At the rear , Alva Schoen is walking up and down before the entrance door .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: He lets people wait for him as if he were a concert conductor !

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: I beg of you , do n't speak !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Hold my tongue , with a head as full of thoughts as mine is !— I absolutely can n't believe she 's changed so awfully much to her advantage there !

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: She is more glorious to look at than I have ever seen her !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: God preserve me from founding my life-happiness on your taste and judgment ! If the sickness has hit her as it has you , I 'm smashed and thru ! You 're leaving the contagious ward like an acrobat-lady who 's had an accident after giving herself up to art . You can scarcely blow your nose any more . First you need a quarter-hour to sort your fingers , and then you have to be mighty careful not to break off the tip .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: What puts * us * under the ground gives * her * health and strength again .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: That 's all right and fine enough . But I do n't think I 'll be travelling off with her this evening .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: You will let your bride journey all alone , after all ?

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: In the first place , the old fellow 's going with her to protect her in case anything serious —. My escort could only be suspicious . And secondly , I must wait here till my costumes are ready . I 'll get across the frontier soon enough alright ,— and I hope in the meantime she 'll put on a little embonpoint , too . Then we 'll get married , provided I can present her before a respectable public . I love the practical in a woman : what theories they make up for themselves are all the same to me . Are n't they to you too , doctor ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: I have n't heard what you were saying .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: I 'd never have got my person mixed up in this plot if she had n't kept tickling my bare pate , before her sentence . If only she does n't start doing too much as soon as she 's out of Germany ! I 'd like best to take her to London for six months , and let her fill up on plum-cakes . In London one expands just from the sea air . And then , too , in London one does n't feel with every swallow of beer as if the hand of fate were at one 's throat .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: I 've been asking myself for a week whether a person who 'd been sentenced to prison could still be made to go as the chief figure in a modern drama .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: If the man would only come , now !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: I 've still got to redeem my properties out of the pawn-shop here , too . Six hundred kilos of the best iron . The baggage-rate on ‘ em is always three times as much as my own ticket , so that the whole junket is n't worth a trowser 's button . When I went into the pawn-shop with ‘ em , dripping with sweat , they asked me if the things were genuine !— I 'd have really done better to have had the costumes made abroad . In Paris , for instance , they see at the first glance where one 's best points are , and bravely lay them bare . But you can n't learn that with bow-legs ; it 's got to be studied on classically shaped people . In this country they 're as scared of naked skin as they are abroad of dynamite bombs . A couple of years ago I was fined fifty marks at the Alhambra Theater , because people could see I had a few hairs on my chest , not enough to make a respectable tooth-brush ! But the Fine Arts Minister opined that the little school-girls might lose their joy in knitting stockings because of it ; and since then I have myself shaved once a month .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: If I did n't need every bit of my creative power now for the “ World-conqueror , ” I might like to test the problem and see what could be done with it . That 's the curse of our young literature : we 're so much too literary . We know only such questions and problems as come up among writers and cultured people . We cannot see beyond the limits of our own professional interests . In order to get back on the trail of a great and powerful art we must move as much as possible among men who 've never read a book in their lives , whom the simplest animal instincts direct in all they do . I 've tried already , with all my might , to work according to those principles — in my “ Earth-spirit . ” The woman who was my model for the chief figure in that , breathes to-day — and has for a year — behind barred windows ; and on that account for some incomprehensible reason the play was only brought to performance by the Society for Free Literature . As long as my father was alive , all the stages of Germany stood open to my creations . That has been vastly changed .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: I 've had a pair of tights made of the tenderest blue-green . If * they * do n't make a success abroad , I 'll sell mouse-traps ! The trunks are so delicate I can n't sit on the edge of a table in ‘ em . The only thing that will disturb the good impression is my awful bald head , which I owe to my active participation in this great conspiracy . To lie in the hospital in perfect health for three months would make a fat pig of the most run-down old hobo . Since coming out I 've fed on nothing but Karlsbad pills . Day and night I have orchestra rehearsals in my intestines . I 'll be so washed out before I get across the frontier that I wo n't be able to lift a bottle-cork .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: How the attendants in the hospital got out of her way yesterday ! That was a refreshing sight . The garden was still as the grave : in the loveliest noon sunlight the convalescents did n't venture out of doors . Away back by the contagious ward she stepped out under the mulberry trees and swayed on her ankles on the gravel . The door-keeper had recognized me , and a young doctor who met me in the corridor shrunk up as tho a revolver shot had struck him . The Sisters vanished into the big rooms or stayed stuck against the walls . When I came back there was not a soul to be seen in the garden or at the gate . No better chance could have been found , if we had had the cursed passports . And now the fellow says he is n't going with her !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: I understand the poor hospital-brothers . One has a bad foot and another has a swollen cheek , and there appears in the midst of them the incarnate death-insurance-agentess ! In the Hall of the Knights , as the blessed division was called from which I organized my spying , when the news got around there that Sister Theophila had departed this life , not one of the fellows could be kept in bed . They scrambled up to the window-bars , if they had to drag their pains along with them by the hundred-weight . I never heard such swearing in my life !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Allow me , Fraulein von Geschwitz , to come back to my proposition once more . Tho my father was shot in this room , still I can see in the murder , as in the punishment , nothing but a horrible misfortune that has befallen * her *; nor do I think that my father , if he had come through alive , would have withdrawn his support from her entirely . Whether your plan for freeing her will succeed still seems to me very doubtful , tho I would n't like to discourage you ; but I can find no words to express the admiration with which your self-sacrifice , your energy , your superhuman scorn of death , inspires me . I do n't believe any man ever risked so much for a woman , let alone for a friend . I am not aware , Fraulein von Geschwitz , how rich you are , but the expenses for what you have accomplished must have exhausted your fortune . May I venture to offer you a loan of 20 , 000 marks — which I should have no trouble raising for you in cash ?

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: How we did rejoice when Sister Theophila was really dead ! From that day on we were free from custody . We changed our beds as we liked . I had done my hair like hers , and copied every tone of her voice . When the professor came he called * her * “ gnaediges Fraulein ” and said to me , “ It 's better living here than in prison ! ” ... When the Sister suddenly was missing , we looked at each other in suspense : we had both been sick five days : now was the deciding moment . Next morning came the assistant .— “ How is Sister Theophila ? ” — “ Dead ! ” — We communicated behind his back , and when he had gone we sank in each other 's arms : “ God be thanked ! God be thanked ! ” — What pains it cost me to keep my darling from betraying how well she already was ! “ You have nine years of prison before you , ” I cried to her early and late . Now they probably wo n't let her stay in the contagious ward three days more !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: I lay in the hospital full three months to spy out the ground , after toilfully peddling together the qualities necessary for such a long stay . Now I act the valet here with you , Dr. Schoen , so that no strange servants may come into the house . Where is the bridegroom who 's ever done so much for his bride ? * My * fortune has also been destroyed .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: When you succeed in developing her into a respectable artiste you will have put the world in debt to you . With the temperament and the beauty that she has to give out of the depths of her nature she can make the most blase public hold its breath . And then , too , she will be protected by * acting * passion from a second time becoming a criminal in reality .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: I 'll soon drive her kiddishness out of her !

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: There he comes !Steps louden in the gallery . Then the curtains part at the head of the stairs and Schigolch in a long black coat with a white sun-shade in his right hand comes down . Thruout the play his speech is interrupted with frequent yawns .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Confound the darkness ! Out-doors the sun burns your eyes out .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: Wearily unwrapping herself .I 'm coming !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Her ladyship has seen no daylight for three days . We live here like in a snuff-box .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Since nine o'clock this morning I 've been round to all the old-clothes-men . Three brand new trunks stuffed full of old trowsers I 've expressed to Buenos Ayres via Bremerhaven . My legs are dangling on me like the tongue of a bell . That 's the new life it 's going to be from now on !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Where are you going to get off to-morrow morning ?

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: I hope not straight into Ox-butter Hotel again !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: I can tell you a fine hotel . I lived there with a lady lion-tamer . The people were born in Berlin .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: Upright in the arm-chair .Come and help me !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Hurries to her and supports her .And you 'll be safer from the police there than on a high tightrope !

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: He means to let you go with her alone this afternoon .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Maybe he 's still suffering from his chillblains !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Do you want me to start my new engagement in bath-robe and slippers ?

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Hm — Sister Theophila would n't have gone to heaven so promptly either , if she had n't felt so affectionate towards our patient .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: She 'll have a different value when one must serve thru a honeymoon with her . Anyway , it can n't hurt her if she gets a little fresh air beforehand .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: A pocketbook in his hand , to Geschwitz who is leaning on a chair-back by the centre table .This holds 10 , 000 marks .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: Thank you , no .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Please take it .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: To Schigolch .Come along , at last !

lg.l: Patience , Fraulein . It 's only a stone 's throw across
Hospital Street . I 'll be here with her in five minutes .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: You 're bringing her here ?

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: I 'm bringing her here . Or do you fear for your health ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: You see that I fear nothing .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: According to the latest wire , the doctor is on his way to Constantinople to have his “ Earth-spirit ” produced before the Sultan by harem-ladies and eunuchs .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Opening the centre door under the gallery .It 's shorter for you thru here .Exeunt Schigolch and Countess Geschwitz . Alva locks the door .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: You were going to give more money to the crazy sky-rocket !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: What has that to do with you ?

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: I get paid like a lamp-lighter , tho I had to demoralize all the Sisters in the hospital . Then came the assistants ’ and the doctors ’ turn , and then —

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Will you seriously inform me that the medical professors let themselves be influenced by you ?

lg.l: With the money those gentlemen cost me I could become
President of the United States !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: But Fraulein von Geschwitz has reimbursed you for every penny that you spent . So far as I know you 're getting a monthly salary of five hundred marks from her besides . It is often pretty hard to believe in your love for the unhappy murderess . When I asked Fraulein von Geschwitz just now to accept my help , it certainly was not to incite your insatiable avarice . The admiration which I have learnt to have for Fraulein von Geschwitz in this affair , I am far from feeling towards you . It is not at all clear to me what claims of any kind you can make upon me . That you chanced to be present at the murder of my father has not yet created the slightest bond of relationship between you and me . On the contrary , I am firmly convinced that if the heroic undertaking of Countess Geschwitz had not come your way you would be lying somewhere to-day without a penny , drunken in the gutter .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: And do you know what would have become of you if you had n't sold for two millions the tuppeny paper your father ran ? You 'd have hitched up with the stringiest sort of ballet-girl and been to-day a stable-boy in the Humpelmeier Circus . What work do you do ? You 've written a drama of horrors in which my bride 's calves are the two chief figures and which no high-class theater will produce . You walking pajamas ! You fresh rag-bag you ! Two years ago I balanced two saddled cavalry-horses on this chest . How that 'll go now , after thisclasping his bald head, is a question sure enough . The foreign girls will get a fine idea of German art when they see the sweat come beading thru my tights at every fresh kilo-weight ! I shall make the whole auditorium stink with my exhalations !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: You 're weak as a dish-clout !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Would to God you were right ! or did you perhaps intend to insult me ? If so , I 'll set the tip of my toe to your jaw so that your tongue 'll crawl along the carpet over there !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Try it !Steps and voices outside .Who is that ...?

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: You can thank God that I have no public here before me !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Who can that be !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: That is my beloved . It 's a full year now since we 've seen each other .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: But how should they be back already ! Who can be coming there ? I expect no one .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Oh the devil , unlock it !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Hide yourself !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: I 'll get behind the portieres . I 've stood there once before , a year ago .Disappears , right . Alva opens the rear door , whereupon Alfred Hugenberg enters , hat in hand .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: With whom have I —.... You ? Are n't you —?

sp.speaker: HUGENBERG
sp.p: Alfred Hugenberg .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: What can I do for you ?

sp.speaker: HUGENBERG
sp.p: I 've come from Muensterburg . I ran away this morning .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: My eyes are bad . I am forced to keep the blinds closed .

sp.speaker: HUGENBERG
sp.p: I need your help . You will not refuse me . I 've got a plan ready . Can anyone hear us ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: What do you mean ? What sort of a plan ?

sp.speaker: HUGENBERG
sp.p: Are you alone ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Yes . What do you want to impart to me ?

sp.speaker: HUGENBERG
sp.p: I 've had two plans already that I let drop . What I shall tell you now has been worked out to the last possible chance . If I had money I should not confide it to you ; I thought about that a long time before coming .... Will you not permit me to set forth to you my design ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Will you kindly tell me just what you are talking about ?

sp.speaker: HUGENBERG
sp.p: She cannot possibly be so indifferent to you that I must tell you that . The evidence * you * gave the coroner helped her more than everything the defending counsel said .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: I beg to decline the supposition .

sp.speaker: HUGENBERG
sp.p: You would say that ; I understand that , of course . But all the same you were her best witness .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: * You * were ! You said my father was about to force her to shoot herself .

sp.speaker: HUGENBERG
sp.p: He was , too . But they did n't believe me . I was n't put on my oath .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Where have you come from now ?

sp.speaker: HUGENBERG
sp.p: From a reform-school I broke out of this morning .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: And what do you have in view ?

sp.speaker: HUGENBERG
sp.p: I 'm trying to get into the confidence of a turnkey .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: What do you mean to live on ?

sp.speaker: HUGENBERG
sp.p: I 'm living with a girl who 's had a child by my father .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Who is your father ?

sp.speaker: HUGENBERG
sp.p: He 's a police captain . I know the prison without ever having been inside it ; and nobody in it will recognize me as I am now . But I do n't count on that at all . I know an iron ladder by which one can get from the first court to the roof and thru an opening there into the attic . There 's no way up to it from inside . But in all five wings boards and laths and great heaps of shavings are lying under the roofs , and I 'll drag them all together in the middle and set fire to them . My pockets are full of matches and all the things used to make fires .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: But then you 'll burn up there !

sp.speaker: HUGENBERG
sp.p: Of course , if I 'm not rescued . But to get into the first court I must have the turnkey in my power , and for that I need money . Not that I mean to bribe him ; that would n't go . I must lend him money to send his three children to the country , and then at four o'clock in the morning when the prisoners of respected families are discharged , I 'll slip in the door . He 'll lock-up behind me and ask me what I 'm after , and I 'll ask him to let me out again in the evening . And before it gets light , I 'm up in the attic .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: How did you escape from the reform-school ?

sp.speaker: HUGENBERG
sp.p: Jumped out the window . I need two hundred marks for the rascal to send his family to the country .

lg.stage: Stepping out of the portieres , right .
lg.l: Will the Herr
Baron have coffee in the music-room or on the veranda ?

sp.speaker: HUGENBERG
sp.p: Where does that man come from ? Out of the same door ! He jumped out of the same door !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: I 've taken him into my service . He is dependable .

sp.speaker: HUGENBERG
sp.p: Grasping his temples .Fool that I am ! Oh , fool !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Oh , yah , we 've seen each other here before ! Cut away now to your vice-mamma . Your kid brother might like to uncle his brothers and sisters . Make your sir-papa the grandfather of his children ! You 're the only thing we 've missed . If you once get into my sight in the next two weeks , I 'll beat your bean up for porridge .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Be quiet , you !

sp.speaker: HUGENBERG
sp.p: I 'm a fool !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: What do you want to do with your fire ? Do n't you know the lady 's been dead three weeks ?

sp.speaker: HUGENBERG
sp.p: Did they cut off her head ?

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: No , she 's got that still . She was mashed by the cholera .

sp.speaker: HUGENBERG
sp.p: That is not true !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: What do you know about it ! There , read it : here !Taking out a paper and pointing to the place .“ The murderess of Dr. Schoen .... ”Gives Hugenberg the paper . He reads :

sp.speaker: HUGENBERG
sp.p: “ The murderess of Dr. Schoen has in some incomprehensible way fallen ill of the cholera in prison . ” It does n't say that she 's dead .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Well , what else do you suppose she is ? She 's been lying in the churchyard three weeks . Back in the left-hand corner behind the rubbish-heap where the little crosses are with no names on them , there she lies under the first one . You 'll know the spot because the grass has n't grown on it . Hang a tin wreath there , and then get back to your nursery-school or I 'll denounce you to the police . I know the female that beguiles her leisure hours with you !

sp.speaker: HUGENBERG
sp.p: To Alva .Is it true that she 's dead ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Thank God , yes !— Please , do not keep me here any longer . My doctor has forbidden me to receive visitors .

sp.speaker: HUGENBERG
sp.p: My future is worth so little now ! I would gladly have given the last scrap of what life is worth to me for her happiness . Heigh-ho ! One way or another I 'll sure go to the devil now !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: If you dare in any way to approach me or the doctor here or my honorable friend Schigolch too near , I 'll inform on you for intended arson . You need three good years , to learn where not to stick your fingers in ! Now get out !

sp.speaker: HUGENBERG
sp.p: Fool !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Get out ! !Throws him out the door . Coming down .I wonder you did n't put your purse at that rogue 's disposal , too !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: I wo n't stand your damned jabbering ! The boy 's little finger is worth more than all you !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: I 've had enough of this Geschwitz 's company ! If my bride is to become a corporation with limited liability , somebody else can go in ahead of me . I propose to make a magnificent trapeze-artist out of her , and willingly risk my life to do it . But then I 'll be master of the house , and will myself indicate what cavaliers she is to receive !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: The boy has what our age lacks : a hero-nature ; therefore , of course , he is going to ruin . Do you remember how before sentence was passed he jumped out of the witness-box and yelled at the justice : “ How do you know what would have become of you if you 'd had to run around the cafes barefoot every night when you were ten years old ?! ”

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: If I could only have given him one in the jaw for that right away ! Thank God , there are jails where scum like that gets some respect for the law pounded into them .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: One like him might have been my model for my “ World-conqueror . ” For twenty years literature has presented nothing but demi-men : men who can beget no children and women who can bear none . That 's called “ The Modern Problem . ”

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: I 've ordered a hippopotamus-whip two inches thick . If that has no success with her , you can fill my cranium with potato-soup . Be it love or be it whipping , female flesh never inquires . Only give it some amusement , and it stays firm and fresh . She is now in her twentieth year , has been married three times and has satisfied a gigantic horde of lovers , and her heart 's desires are at last pretty plain . But the man 's got to have the seven deadly sins on his forehead , or she honors him not . If he looks as if a dog-catcher had spat him out on the street , then , with such women-folks , he need n't be afraid of a prince ! I 'll rent a garage fifty feet high and break her in there ; and when she 's learnt the first diving-leap without breaking her neck I 'll pull on a black coat and not stir a finger the rest of my life . When she 's educated practically it does n't cost a woman half as much trouble to support her husband as the other way round , if only the man takes care of the mental labor for her , and does n't let the sense of the family go to wreck .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: I have learnt to rule humanity and drive it in harness before me like a well-broken four-in-hand ,— but that boy sticks in my head . Really , I can still take private lessons in the scorn of the world from that school-boy !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: She 'll just comfortably let her hide be papered with thousand-mark bills ! I 'll extract salaries out of the directors with a centrifugal pump . I know their kind . When they do n't need a man , let him shine their shoes for them ; but when they must have an artiste they cut her down from the very gallows with their own hands and with the most entangling compliments .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: In my situation there 's nothing more in the world to fear — but death . In the realm of sensation I am the poorest beggar . But I can no longer scrape up the moral courage to exchange my established position for the excitements of the wild , adventurous life !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: She had sent Papa Schigolch and me together in chase of some strong antidote for sleeplessness . We each got a twenty-mark piece for expenses . There we see the youngster sitting in the Night-light Cafe . He was sitting like a criminal on the prisoner 's bench . Schigolch sniffed at him from all sides , and remarked , “ He is still virgin . ”Up in the gallery , dragging steps are heard .There she is ! The future magnificent trapeze-artiste of the present age !

div.stage: The curtains part at the stair-head , and Lulu , supported by Schigolch , and in a black dress , slowly and wearily descends .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Hui , old mold ! We 've still to get over the frontier to-day .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Glaring stupidly at Lulu .Thunder of heaven ! Death !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Speaks , to the end of the act , in the gayest tones .Slowly ! You 're pinching my arm !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: How did you ever get the shamelessness to break out of prison with such a wolf 's face ? !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Stop your snout !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: I 'll run for the police ! I 'll give information ! This scarecrow let herself be seen in tights ?! The padding alone would cost two months ’ salary !— You 're the most perfidious swindler that ever had lodging in Ox-butter Hotel !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Kindly refrain from insulting the lady !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Insulting you call that ?! For this gnawed bone 's sake I 've worn myself away ! I can n't earn my own living ! I 'll be a clown if I can still stand firm under a broom-stick ! But let the lightning strike me on the spot if I do n't worm ten thousand marks a year for life out of your tricks and frauds ! I can tell you that ! A pleasant trip ! I 'm going for the police !Exit .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Run , run !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: He 'll take good care of himself !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: We 're rid of * him *!— And now some black coffee for the lady !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: At the table left .Here is coffee , ready to pour .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: I must look after the sleeping-car tickets .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Brightly .Oh , freedom ! Thank God for freedom !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: I 'll be back for you in half an hour . We 'll celebrate our departure in the station-restaurant . I 'll order a supper that 'll keep us going till to-morrow .— Good morning , doctor .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Good evening .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Pleasant rest !— Thanks , I know every door-handle here . So long ! Have a good time !Exit .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: I have n't seen a room for a year and a half . Curtains , chairs , pictures ....

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Wo n't you drink it ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: I 've swallowed enough black coffee these five days . Have you any brandy ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: I 've got some elixir de Spaa .

lg.l: That reminds one of old times .
lg.stage: Looks round the hall while Alva fills two glasses .
lg.l: Where 's my picture gone ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: I 've got it in my room , so no one shall see it here .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Bring it down here now .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Did n't you even lose your vanity in prison ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: How anxious at heart one gets when one has n't seen herself for months ! One day I got a brand-new dust-pan . When I swept up at seven in the morning I held the back of it up before my face . Tin does n't flatter , but I took pleasure in it all the same .— Bring the picture down from your room . Shall I come too ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: No , Heaven 's sake ! You must spare yourself !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: I 've been sparing myself long enough now !Alva goes out , right , to get the picture .He has heart-trouble ; but to have to plague one 's self with imagination fourteen months !... He kisses with the fear of death on him , and his two knees shake like a frozen vagabond 's . In God 's name .... In this room — if only I had not shot his father in the back !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Returns with the picture of Lulu in the Pierrot-dress .It 's covered with dust . I had leant it against the fire-place , face to the wall .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: You did n't look at it all the time I was away ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: I had so much business to attend to , with the sale of our paper and everything . Countess Geschwitz would have liked to have hung it up in her house , but she had to be prepared for search-warrants .He puts the picture on the easel .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Merrily .Now the poor monster is learning the joys of life in Hotel Ox-butter by her own experience .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Even now I do n't understand how events hang together .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Oh , Geschwitz arranged it all very cleverly . I must admire her inventiveness . But the cholera must have raged fearfully in Hamburg this summer ; and on that she founded her plan for freeing me . She took a course in hospital nursing here , and when she had the necessary documents she journeyed to Hamburg with them and nursed the cholera patients . At the first opportunity that offered she put on the underclothes in which a sick woman had just died and which really ought to have been burnt . The same morning she traveled back here and came to see me in prison . In my cell , while the wardress was outside , we , as quick as we could , exchanged underclothes .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: So that was the reason why the Countess and you fell sick of the cholera the same day !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Exactly , that was it ! Geschwitz of course was instantly brought from her house to the contagious ward in the hospital . But with me , too , they could n't think of any other place to take me . So there we lay in one room in the contagious ward behind the hospital , and from the first day Geschwitz put forth all her art to make our two faces as like each other as possible . Day before yesterday she was let out as cured . Just now she came back and said she 'd forgotten her watch . I put on her clothes , she slipped into my prison frock , and then I came away .With pleasure .Now she 's lying over there as the murderess of Dr. Schoen .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: So far as outward appearance goes you can still agree with the picture as much as ever .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: I 'm a little peaked in the face , but otherwise I 've lost nothing . Only one gets incredibly nervous in prison .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: You looked horribly sick when you came in .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: I had to , to get our necks out of the noose .— And you ? What have you done in this year and a half ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: I 've had a succes d'estime in literary circles with a play I wrote about you .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Who 's your sweetheart now ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: An actress I 've rented a house for in Karl Street .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Does she love you ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: How should I know that ? I have n't seen the woman for six weeks .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Can you stand that ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: You will never understand that . With me there 's the closest alternation between my sensuality and mental creativeness . So towards you , for example , I have only the choice of regarding you artistically or of loving you .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: In a fairy-story tone .I used to dream every other night that I 'd fallen into the hands of a sadic .... Come , give me a kiss !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: It 's shining in your eyes like the water in a deep well one has just thrown a stone into .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Come !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Kisses her .Your lips have got pretty thin , anyway .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Come !Pushes him into a chair and seats herself on his knee .Do you shudder at me ?— In Hotel Ox-butter we all got a luke-warm bath every four weeks . The wardresses took that opportunity to search our pockets as soon as we were in the water .She kisses him passionately .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Oh , oh !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: You 're afraid that when I 'm away you could n't write any more poems about me ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: On the contrary , I shall write a dithyramb upon thy glory .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: I 'm only sore about the hideous shoes I 'm wearing .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: They do not encroach upon your charms . Let us be thankful for the favor of this moment .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: I do n't feel at all like that to-day .— Do you remember the costume ball where I was dressed like a knight 's squire ? How those wine-full women ran after me that time ? Geschwitz crawled round , round my feet , and begged me to step on her face with my cloth shoes .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Come , dear heart !

lg.stage: In the tone with which one quiets a restless child .
lg.l: Quietly ! I shot your father .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: I do not love thee less for that . One kiss !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Bend your head back .She kisses him with deliberation .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: You hold back the fire of my soul with the most dexterous art . And your breast breathes so virginly too . Yet if it were n't for your two great , dark , childish eyes , I must needs have thought you the cunningest whore that ever hurled a man to destruction .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: In high spirits .Would God I were ! Come over the border with us to-day ! Then we can see each other as often as we will , and we 'll get more pleasure from each other than now .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Through this dress I feel your body like a symphony . These slender ankles , this cantabile . This rapturous crescendo . And these knees , this capriccio . And the powerful andante of lust !— How peacefully these two slim rivals press against each other in the consciousness that neither equals the other in beauty — till their capricious mistress wakes up and the rival lovers separate like the two hostile poles . I shall sing your praises so that your senses shall whirl !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Merrily .Meanwhile I 'll bury my hands in your hair .She does so .But here we 'll be disturbed .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: You have robbed me of my reason !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Are n't you coming with me to-day ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: But the old fellow 's going with you !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: He wo n't turn up again .— Is not that the divan on which your father bled to death ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Be still . Be still ....

stage.stage: A spacious salon in white stucco . In the rear-wall , between two high mirrors , a wide folding doorway showing in the rear room a big card-table surrounded by Turkish upholstered chairs . In the left wall two doors , the upper one to the entrance-hall , the lower to the dining-room . Between them a rococo-console with a white marble top , and above it Lulu 's Pierrot-picture in a narrow gold frame let into the wall . Two other doors , right ; near the lower one a small table . Wide and brightly-covered chairs stand about , with thin legs and fragile arms ; and in the middle is a sofa of the same style ( Louis XV . ) .

A large company is moving about the salon in lively conversation . The men —* Alva *, * Rodrigo *, Marquis * Casti-Piani *, Banker * Puntschu *, and Journalist * Heilmann *— are in evening dress . * Lulu * wears a white Directoire dress with huge sleeves and white lace falling freely from belt to feet . Her arms are in white kid gloves , her hair done high with a little tuft of white feathers . * Geschwitz * is in a bright blue hussar-waist trimmed with white fur and laced with silver braid , a tall tight collar with a white bow and stiff cuffs with huge ivory links . * Magelone * is in bright rainbow-colored shot silk with very wide sleeves , long narrow waist , and three ruffles of spiral rose-colored ribbons and violet bouquets . Her hair is parted in the middle and drawn low over her temples . On her forehead is a mother-of-pearl ornament , held by a fine chain under her hair . * Kadidia *, her daughter , twelve years old , has bright-green satin gaiters which yet leave visible the tops of her white silk socks , and a white-lace-covered dress with bright-green narrow sleeves , pearl-gray gloves , and free black hair under a big bright-green hat with white feathers . * Bianetta * is in dark-green velvet , the collar sewn with pearls , and a full skirt , its hem embroidered with great false topazes set in silver . * Ludmilla Steinherz * is in a glaring summer frock striped red and blue .
Rodrigo stands , centre , a full glass in his hand .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Ladies and gentlemen — I beg your pardon — please be quiet — I drink — permit me to drink — for this is the birthday party of our amiable hostess —taking Lulu 's armof Countess Adelaide d'Oubra — damned and done for !— I drink therefore —— and so forth , go to it , ladies !All surround Lulu and clink with her . Alva presses Rodrigo 's hand .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: I congratulate you .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: I 'm sweating like a roast pig .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: To Lulu .Let 's see if everything 's in order in the card-room .Alva and Lulu exeunt , rear . Bianetta speaks to Rodrigo .

sp.speaker: BIANETTA
sp.p: They were telling me just now you were the strongest man in the world .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: That I am . May I put my strength at your disposal ?

sp.speaker: MAGELONE
sp.p: I love sharp-shooters better . Three months ago a sharp-shooter stepped into the casino and every time he went “ bang ! ” I felt like this .She wriggles her hips .

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: Who speaks thruout the act in a bored and weary tone , to Magelone .Say , dearie , how does it happen we see your nice little princess here for the first time to-night ?Meaning Kadidia .

sp.speaker: MAGELONE
sp.p: Do you really find her so delightful ?— She is still in the convent . She must be back in school again on Monday .

sp.speaker: KADIDIA
sp.p: What did you say , mama ?

sp.speaker: MAGELONE
sp.p: I was just telling the gentleman that you got the highest mark in geometry last week .

sp.speaker: HEILMANN
sp.p: Some pretty hair she 's got !

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: Just look at her feet : the way she walks !

sp.speaker: PUNTSCHU
sp.p: By god , she 's got breeding !

sp.speaker: MAGELONE
sp.p: Smiling .But my dear sirs , take pity on her ! She 's nothing but a child still !

sp.speaker: PUNTSCHU
sp.p: That 'd trouble me damned little !To Heilmann .I 'd give ten years of my life if I could initiate the young lady into the ceremonies of our secret society !

sp.speaker: MAGELONE
sp.p: But you wo n't get me to consent to that for a million . I wo n't have the child 's youth ruined , the way mine was !

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: Confessions of a lovely soul !To Magelone .Would you not agree , either , for a set of real diamonds ?

sp.speaker: MAGELONE
sp.p: Do n't brag ! You 'll give as few real diamonds to me as to my child . You know that quite the best yourself .Kadidia goes into the rear room .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: But is nobody at all going to play , this evening ?

sp.speaker: LUDMILLA
sp.p: Why , of course , comtesse . I 'm counting on it very much , for one !

sp.speaker: BIANETTA
sp.p: Then let 's take our places right away . The gentlemen will soon come then .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: May I ask you to excuse me just a second . I must say a word to my friend .

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: Offering his arm to Bianetta .May I have the honor to be your partner ? You always hold such a lucky hand !

sp.speaker: LUDMILLA
sp.p: Now just give me your other arm and then lead us into the gambling-hell .The three go off so , rear .

sp.speaker: MAGELONE
sp.p: Say , Mr. Puntschu , have you still got a few Jungfrau shares for me , maybe ?

sp.speaker: PUNTSCHU
sp.p: Jungfrau-shares ?To Heilmann .The lady means the stock of the funicular railway on the Jungfrau . The Jungfrau , you know ,— the Virgin — is a mountain up which they want to build a wire railway .To Magelone .You know , just so there may be no confusion ;— and how easy that would be in this select circle !— Yes , I still have some four thousand Jungfrau-shares , but I should like to keep those for myself . There wo n't be such another chance soon of making a little fortune out of hand .

sp.speaker: HEILMANN
sp.p: I 've only one lone share of this Jungfrau-stock so far . I should like to have more , too .

sp.speaker: PUNTSCHU
sp.p: I 'll try , Mr. Heilmann , to look after some for you . But I 'll tell you beforehand you 'll have to pay drug-store prices for them !

sp.speaker: MAGELONE
sp.p: My fortune-teller advised me to look about me in time . All my savings are in Jungfrau-shares now . If it does n't turn out well , Mr. Puntschu , I 'll scratch your eyes out !

sp.speaker: PUNTSCHU
sp.p: I am perfectly sure of my affairs , my dearie !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Who has come back from the card-room , to Magelone .I can guarantee your fears are absolutely unfounded . I paid very dear for my Jungfrau-stock and have n't regretted it a minute . They 're going up steadily from day to day . There never was such a thing before .

sp.speaker: MAGELONE
sp.p: All the better , if you 're right .Taking Puntschu 's arm .Come , my friend , let 's try our luck now at baccarat .All go out , rear , except Geschwitz and Rodrigo who scribbles something on a piece of paper and folds it up , then notices Geschwitz .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Hm , madam countess —Geschwitz starts and shrinks .Do I look as dangerous as that ?To himself .I must make a bon mot .Aloud .May I perhaps make so bold —

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: You can go to the devil !

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: As he leads Lulu in .Permit me a word or two .

lg.stage: Not noticing Rodrigo who presses his note into her hand .
lg.l: Oh , as many as you like .
lg.stage: Rodrigo bows and goes out , rear .

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: To Geschwitz .Leave us alone !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: To Casti-Piani .Have I hurt you again in any way ?

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: Since Geschwitz does not stir .Are you deaf ?Geschwitz , sighing deeply , goes out , rear .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Just say straight out how much you want .

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: With money you can no longer serve me .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: What makes you think that we have no more money ?

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: You handed out the last bit of it to me yesterday .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: If you 're sure of that then I suppose it 's so .

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: You 're down on the bare ground , you and your writer .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Then why all the words ?— If you want to have me for yourself you need not first threaten me with execution .

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: I know that . But I 've told you more than once that you wo n't be my downfall . I have n't sucked you dry because you loved me , but loved you in order to suck you . Bianetta is more to my taste from top to bottom than you . You set out the choicest sweetmeats , and after one has frittered his time away at them he finds he 's hungrier than before . You 've loved too long , even for our present relations . With a healthy young man , you only ruin his nervous system . But you 'll fit all the more perfectly in the position I have sought out for you .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: You 're crazy ! Have I commissioned you to find a position for me ?

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: I told you , though , that I was an appointments-agent .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: You told me you were a police spy .

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: One can n't live on that alone . I was an appointments-agent originally , till I blundered over a minister 's daughter I 'd got a position for in Valparaiso . The little darling in her childhood 's dreams imagined the life even more intoxicating than it is , and complained of it to Mama . On that , they nabbed me ; but by reliable demeanor I soon enough won the confidence of the criminal police and they sent me here on a hundred and fifty marks a month , because they were tripling our contingent here on account of these everlasting bomb-explosions . But who can get along on a hundred and fifty marks a month ? My colleagues get women to support them ; but , of course , I found it more convenient to take up my former calling again ; and of the numberless adventuresses of the best families of the entire world , whom chance brings together here , I have already forwarded many a young creature hungry for life to the place of her natural vocation .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Decisively .I would n't do in that business .

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: Your views on that question make no difference whatever to me . The department of justice will pay anyone who delivers the murderess of Dr. Schoen into the hands of the police a thousand marks . I only need to whistle for the constable who 's standing down at the corner to have earned a thousand marks . Against that , the House of Oikonomopulos in Cairo bids sixty pounds for you — twelve hundred marks — two hundred more than the Attorney General . And , besides , I am still so far a friend of mankind that I prefer to help my loves to happiness , not plunge them into misfortune .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: As before .The life in such a house can never make a woman of my stamp happy . When I was fifteen , that might have happened to me . I was desperate then — thought I should never be happy . I bought a revolver , and ran one night bare-foot thru the deep snow over the bridge to the park to shoot myself there . But then by good luck I lay three months in the hospital without setting eyes on a man , and in that time my eyes opened and I got to know myself . Night after night in my dreams I saw the man for whom I was created and who was created for me , and then when I was let out on the men again I was no longer a silly goose . Since then I can see on a man , in a pitch-dark night and a hundred feet away , whether we 're suited to each other ; and if I sin against that insight I feel the next day dirtied , body and soul , and need weeks to get over the loathing I have for myself . And now you imagine I 'll give myself to every and any Tom and Harry !

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: Toms and Harries do n't patronize Oikonomopulos of Cairo . His custom consists of Scottish lords , Russian dignitaries , Indian governors , and our jolly Rhineland captains of industry . I must only guarantee that you speak French . With your gift for languages you 'll quickly enough learn as much English , besides , as you 'll need to get on with . And you 'll reside in a royally furnished apartment with an outlook on the minarets of the El Azhar Mosque , and walk around all day on Persian carpets as thick as your fist , and dress every evening in a fabulous Paris gown and drink as much champagne as your customers can pay for , and , finally , you 'll even remain , up to a certain point , your own mistress . If the man does n't please you , you need n't bring him any reciprocal feelings . Just let him give in his card , and then —Shrugs , and snaps his fingers .If the ladies did n't get used to that the whole business would be simply impossible , because every one after the first four weeks would go headlong to the devil .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Her voice shaking .I do believe that since yesterday you 've got a screw loose somewhere . Am I to understand that the Egyptian will pay fifteen hundred francs for a person whom he 's never seen ?

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: I took the liberty of sending him your pictures .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Those pictures that I gave you , you 've sent to him ?

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: You see he can value them better than I . The picture in which you stand before the mirror as Eve he 'll probably hang up at the house-door , after you 've got there .... And then there 's one thing more for you to notice : with Oikonomopulos in Cairo you 'll be safer from your blood-hounds than if you crept into a Canadian wilderness . It is n't so easy to transport an Egyptian courtesan to a German prison ,— first , on account of the mere expense , and second , from fear of coming too close to eternal Justice .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Proudly , in a clear voice .What 's your eternal Justice to do with me ! You can see as plain as your five fingers I sha n't let myself be locked up in any such amusement-place !

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: Then do you want me to whistle for the policeman ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: In wonder .Why do n't you simply ask me for twelve hundred marks , if you want the money ?

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: I want for no money ! And I also do n't ask for it because you 're dead broke .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: We still have thirty thousand marks .

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: In Jungfrau-stock ! I never have anything to do with stock . The Attorney-General pays in the national currency , and Oikonomopulos pays in English gold . You can be on board early to-morrow . The passage does n't last much more than five days . In two weeks at most you 're in safety . Here you are nearer to prison than anywhere . It 's a wonder which I , as one of the secret police , cannot understand , that you two have been able to live for a full year unmolested . But just as I came on the track of your antecedents , so any day , with your mighty consumption of men , one of my colleagues may make the happy discovery . Then I may just wipe my mouth , and you spend in prison the most enjoyable years of your life . If you will kindly decide quickly . The train goes at 12. 30 . If we have n't struck a bargain before eleven , I whistle up the policeman . If we have , I pack you , just as you stand , into a carriage , drive you to the station , and to-morrow escort you on board ship .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: But is it possible you can be serious in all this ?

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: Do n't you understand that I can act now only for your bodily rescue ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: I 'll go with you to America or to China , but I can n't let myself be sold of my own accord ! That is worse than prison !

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: Drawing a letter from his pocket .Just read this effusion ! I 'll read it to you . Here 's the postmark “ Cairo , ” so you wo n't believe I work with forged documents . The girl is a Berliner , was married two years and to a man whom you would have envied her , a former comrade of mine . He travels now for the Hamburg Colonial Company ....

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Merrily .Then perhaps he * visits * his wife occasionally ?

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: That is not incredible . But hear this impulsive expression of her feelings . My white-slave traffic seems to me absolutely no more honorable than the very best judge would tax it with being , but a cry of joy like this lets me feel a certain moral satisfaction for a moment . I am proud to earn my money by scattering happiness with full hands .Reads .“ Dear Mr. Meyer ” — that 's my name as a white-slave trader — “ when you go to Berlin , please go right away to the conservatory on the Potsdamer Strasse and ask for Gusti von Rosenkron — the most beautiful woman that I 've ever seen in nature — delightful hands and feet , naturally small waist , straight back , full body , big eyes and short nose — just the sort you like best . I have written to her already . She has no prospects with her singing . Her mother has n't a penny . Sorry she 's already twenty-two , but she 's pining for love . Ca n't marry , because absolutely without means . I have spoken with Madame . They 'd like to take another German , if she 's well educated and musical . Italians and Frenchwomen can n't compete with us , ‘ cause of too little culture . If you should see Fritz ” — Fritz is the husband ; he 's getting a divorce , of course ,— “ tell him it was all a bore . He did n't know any better , nor did I either . ” Now come the exact details —

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Goaded .I can not sell the only thing that ever was my own !

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: Let me read some more .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: As before .This very evening , I 'll hand over to you our entire wealth .

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: Believe me , for God 's sake , I 've * got * your last red cent ! If we have n't left this house before eleven , you and your lot will be transported to-morrow in a police-car to Germany .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: You * can n't * give me up !

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: Do you think that would be the worst thing I can have done in my life ?... I must , in case we go to-night , have just a brief word with Bianetta .He goes into the card-room , leaving the door open behind him . Lulu stares before her , mechanically crumpling up the note that Rodrigo stuck into her hand , which she has held in her fingers thruout the dialog . Alva , behind the card-table , gets up , a bill in his hand , and comes into the salon .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: To Lulu .Brilliantly ! It 's going brilliantly ! Geschwitz is wagering her last shirt . Puntschu has promised me ten more Jungfrau-shares . Steinherz is making her little gains and profits .Exit , lower right .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: I in a bordell ?—She reads the paper she holds , and laughs madly .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Coming back with a cash-box in his hand .Are n't you going to play , too ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Oh , yes , surely — why not ?

lg.l: By the way , it 's in the Berliner Tageblatt to-day that Alfred
Hugenberg has hurled himself over the stairs in prison .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Is he too in prison ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Only in a sort of house of detention .Exit , rear . Lulu is about to follow , but Countess Geschwitz meets her in the door-way .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: You are going because I come ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Resolutely .No , God knows . But when you come then I go .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: You have defrauded me of all the good things of this world that I still possessed . You might at the very least preserve the outward forms of politeness in your intercourse with me .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: As before .I am as polite to you as to any other woman . I only beg you to be equally so to me .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: Have you forgotten the passionate endearments by which , while we lay together in the hospital , you seduced me into letting myself be locked into prison for you ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Well , why else did you bring me down with the cholera beforehand ? I swore very different things to myself , even while it was going on , from what I had to promise you ! I am shaken with horror at the thought that that should ever become reality !

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: Then you cheated me consciously , deliberately ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Gaily .What have you been cheated of , then ? Your physical advantages have found so enthusiastic an admirer here , that I ask myself if I wo n't have to give piano lessons once more , to keep alive ! No seventeen-year-old child could make a man madder with love than you , a pervert , are making him , poor fellow , by your shrewishness .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: Of whom are you speaking ? I do n't understand a word .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: As before .I 'm speaking of your acrobat , of Rodrigo Quast . He 's an athlete : he balances two saddled cavalry horses on his chest . Can a woman desire anything more glorious ? He told me just now that he 'd jump into the water to-night if you did not take pity on him .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: I do not envy you this cleverness with which you torture the helpless victims sacrificed to you by their inscrutable destiny . My own plight has not yet wrung from me the pity that I feel for you . I feel free as a god when I think to what creatures * you * are enslaved .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Who do you mean ?

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: Casti-Piani , upon whose forehead the most degenerate baseness is written in letters of fire !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Be silent ! I 'll kick you , if you speak ill of * him *. He loves me with an uprightness against which your most venturous self-sacrifices are poor as beggary ! He gives me such proofs of self-denial as reveal * you * for the first time in all your loathsomeness ! You did n't get finished in your mother 's womb , neither as woman nor as man . You have no human nature like the rest of us . The stuff did n't go far enough for a man , and for a woman you got too much brain into your skull . That 's the reason you 're crazy ! Turn to Miss Bianetta ! She can be had for everything for pay ! Press a gold-piece into her hand and she 'll belong to you .All the company save Kadidia throng in out of the card-room .For the Lord 's sake , what has happened ?

sp.speaker: PUNTSCHU
sp.p: Nothing whatever ! We 're thirsty , that 's all .

sp.speaker: MAGELONE
sp.p: Everybody has won . We can n't believe it .

sp.speaker: BIANETTA
sp.p: It seems I have won a whole fortune !

sp.speaker: LUDMILLA
sp.p: Do n't boast of it , my child . That is n't lucky .

sp.speaker: MAGELONE
sp.p: But the bank has won , too ! How is that * possible *?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: It is colossal , where all the money comes from !

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: Let us not ask ! Enough that we need not spare the champagne .

sp.speaker: HEILMANN
sp.p: I can pay for a supper in a respectable restaurant afterwards , anyway !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: To the buffet , ladies ! Come to the buffet !All exeunt , lower left .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Holding Lulu back .Un momong , my heart . Have you read my billet-doux ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Threaten me with discovery as much as you like ! I have no more twenty thousands to dispose of .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Do n't lie to me , you punk ! You 've still got forty thousand in Jungfrau-stock . Your so-called spouse has just been bragging of it himself !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Then turn to * him * with your blackmailing ! It 's all one to me what he does with his money .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Thank you ! With that blockhead I 'd need twice twenty-four hours to make him grasp what I was talking about . And then come his explanations , that make one deathly sick ; and meanwhile my bride writes me “ It 's all up ! ” and I can just hang a hurdy-gurdy over my shoulder .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Have you got engaged here , then ?

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Maybe I ought to have asked your permission first ? What were my thanks here that I freed you from prison at the cost of my health ? You abandoned me ! I might have had to be a baggage-man if this girl had n't taken me up ! At my very first entrance , right away , they threw a velvet-covered arm-chair at my head ! This country is too decadent to value genuine shows of strength any more . If I 'd been a boxing kangaroo they 'd have interviewed me and put my picture in all the papers . Thank heaven , I 'd already made the acquaintance of my Celestine . She 's got the savings of twenty years deposited with the government ; and she loves me just for myself . She does n't aim only at vulgar things , like you . She 's had three children by an American bishop — all of the greatest promise . Day after to-morrow we 'll get married by the registrar .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: You have my blessing .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Your blessing * can * be stolen from me . I 've told my bride I had twenty thousand in stock at the bank .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Amused .And after that he boasts the person loves him for himself !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: She honors in me the man of mind , not the man of might as you and all the others have done . That 's over now . First they tore the clothes from one 's body and then they waltzed around with the chambermaid . I 'll be a skeleton before I 'll let myself in again for such diversions !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Then why the devil do you pursue the unfortunate Geschwitz with your attentions ?

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Because the creature is of noble blood . I 'm a man of the world , and can do distinguished conversation better than any of you . But nowwith a gesturemy talk is hanging out of my mouth ! Will you get me the money before to-morrow evening or wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: I have no money .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: I 'll have hen-droppings in my head before I 'll let myself be put off with that ! He 'll give you his last cent if you 'll only do your damned duty once ! You lured the poor lad here , and now he can see where to scare up a suitable engagement for his accomplishments .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: What has it to do with you if he wastes his money with women or at cards ?

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Do you absolutely * want *, then , to throw the last penny that his father earned by his paper into the jaws of this rapacious pack ? You 'll make four people happy if you 'll not take things too exactly and sacrifice yourself for a beneficent purpose ! Has it got to be only Casti-Piani * forever *?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Lightly .Shall I ask him perhaps to light you down the stairs ?

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: As you wish , countess ! If I do n't get the twenty thousand marks by to-morrow evening , I make a statement to the police and your court has an end . Auf Wiedersehen !Heilmann enters , breathless , upper right .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: You 're looking for Miss Magelone ? She 's not here .

sp.speaker: HEILMANN
sp.p: No , I 'm looking for something else —

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Taking him to the entry-door , opposite him .Second door on the left .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: To Rodrigo .Did you learn that from your bride ?

sp.speaker: HEILMANN
sp.p: Bumping into Puntschu in the doorway .Excuse me , my angel !

sp.speaker: PUNTSCHU
sp.p: Ah , it 's you . Miss Magelone 's waiting for you in the lift .

sp.speaker: HEILMANN
sp.p: You go up with her , please . I 'll be right back .He hurries out , left . Lulu goes out at lower left . Rodrigo follows her .

sp.speaker: PUNTSCHU
sp.p: Some heat , that ! If I do n't cut off * your * ears , you 'll cut ‘ em off me ! If I can n't hire out my Jehoshaphat , I 've just got to help myself with my brains ! Wo n't they get wrinkled , my brains ! Wo n't they get indisposed ! Wo n't they need to bathe in Eau de Cologne !Bob , a groom in a red jacket , tight leather breeches , and twinkling riding-boots , 15 years old , brings in a telegram .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: Mr. Puntschu , the banker !

lg.stage: Breaks open the telegram and murmurs :
lg.l: “ Jungfrau
Funicular Stock fallen to — ” Ay , ay , so goes the world !
Wait !
Tell me — what 's your name ?

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: Well , it 's really Freddy , but they call me Bob , because that 's the fashion now .

sp.speaker: PUNTSCHU
sp.p: How old are you ?

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: Fifteen .

sp.speaker: KADIDIA
sp.p: Enters hesitatingly from lower left .I beg your pardon , can you tell me if mama is here ?

sp.speaker: PUNTSCHU
sp.p: No , my dear .Aside .Devil , she 's got breeding !

sp.speaker: KADIDIA
sp.p: I 'm hunting all over for her ; I can n't find her anywhere .

lg.l: Your mama will turn up again soon , as true as my name 's
Puntschu !
And that pair of breeches ! God of
Justice ! It gets uncanny !

sp.speaker: KADIDIA
sp.p: Have n't * you * seen my mama , perhaps ?

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: No , but you only need to come with me .

sp.speaker: KADIDIA
sp.p: Where is she then ?

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: She 's gone up in the lift . Come along .

sp.speaker: KADIDIA
sp.p: No , no , I can n't go up with you .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: We can hide up there in the corridor .

sp.speaker: KADIDIA
sp.p: No , no , I can n't come , or I 'll be scolded .Magelone , terribly excited , rushes in , upper left , and possesses herself of Kadidia .

sp.speaker: MAGELONE
sp.p: Ha , there you are at last , you common creature !

sp.speaker: KADIDIA
sp.p: Crying .O mama , mama , I was hunting for you !

sp.speaker: MAGELONE
sp.p: Hunting for me ? Did I tell you to hunt for me ? What have you had to do with this fellow ?Heilmann , Alva , Ludmilla , Puntschu , Geschwitz , and Lulu enter , lower left . Bob has withdrawn .Now do n't bawl before all the people on me ; look out , I tell you !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: As they all surround Kadidia .But you 're crying , sweetheart ! Why are you crying ?

sp.speaker: PUNTSCHU
sp.p: By God , she 's really been crying ! Who 's done anything to hurt you , little goddess ?

sp.speaker: LUDMILLA
sp.p: Kneels before her and folds her in her arms .Tell me , cherub , what bad thing has happened . Do you want a cookie ? Do you want some chocolate ?

sp.speaker: MAGELONE
sp.p: It 's just nerves . The child 's getting them much too soon . It would be the best thing if no one paid any attention to her !

sp.speaker: PUNTSCHU
sp.p: That sounds like you ! You 're a pretty mother ! The courts 'll yet take the child away from you and appoint me her guardian !Stroking Kadidia 's cheeks .Is n't that so , my little goddess ?

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: I should be glad if we started the baccarat again at last ?All go into the card-room . Lulu is held back at the door by Bob .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: When Bob has whispered to her .Certainly ! Let him come in !Bob opens the door and lets Schigolch enter , in evening dress , his patent-leather shoes much worn , and keeping on his shabby opera hat .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: With a look at Bob .Where d 'd you get him from ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: The circus .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: How much does he get ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Ask him if it interests you .To Bob .Shut the doors .Bob goes out lower left , shutting the door behind him .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Sitting down .The truth is , I 'm in need of money . I 've hired a flat for my mistress .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Have you taken another mistress here , too ?

lg.l: She 's from Frankfort . In her youth she was mistress to the
King of Naples . She tells me every day she was once very bewitching .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Outwardly with complete composure .Does she need the money very badly ?

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: She wants to fit up her own apartments . Such sums are of no account to * you *.Lulu is suddenly overcome with a fit of weeping .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Flinging herself at Schigolch .O God Omnipotent !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Patting her .Well ? What is it now ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Sobbing violently .It 's too horrible !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Draws her onto his knee and holds her in his arms like a little child .Hm — You 're trying to do too much , child . You must go to bed , now and then , with a story .— Cry , that 's right , cry it all out . It used to shake you just so fifteen years ago . Nobody has screamed since then , the way you could scream ! You did n't wear any white tufts on your head then , nor any transparent stockings on your legs : you had neither shoes nor stockings then .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Crying .Take me home with you ! Take me home with you to-night ! Please ! We 'll find carriages enough downstairs !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: I 'll take you with me ; I 'll take you with me .— What is it ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: It 's going round my neck ! I 'm to be shown up !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: By who ? Who 's showing you up ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: The acrobat .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: With the utmost composure .I 'll look after him .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Look after him ! * Please *, look after him ! Then do with me what you will !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: If he comes to me , he 's done for . My window is over the water . Butshaking his headhe wo n't come ; he wo n't come .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: What number do you live at ?

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: 376 , the last house before the hippodrome .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: I 'll send him there . He 'll come with the crazy person that creeps about my feet . He 'll come this very evening . Go home and let them find it comfortable .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Just let them come .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: To-morrow bring the gold rings he wears in his ears .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Has he got rings in his ears ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: You can take them out before you let him down . He does n't notice anything when he 's drunk .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: And then , child — what then ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Then I 'll give you the money for your mistress .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: I call that pretty stingy .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: And whatever else you want ! What I have !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: It 's pretty near ten years since we knew each other .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Is that all ?— But you 've got a mistress .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: My Frankforter is no longer of to-day .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: But then swear !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Have n't I always kept my word to you ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Swear that you 'll look after him !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: I 'll look after him .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Swear it to me ! Swear it to me !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Puts his hand on her ankle .By everything that 's holy ! To-night , if he comes —

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: By everything that 's holy !— How cool that is !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: How hot this is !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Drive straight home . They 'll come in half-an-hour ! Take a carriage !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: I 'm going .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Quick ! Please !— — All-powerful —

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Why do you stare at me so again already ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Nothing —....

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Well ? Is your tongue frozen on you ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: My garter 's broken .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: What if it is ? Is that all ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: What does that augur ?

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: What does it ? I 'll fasten it for you if you 'll keep still .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: That augurs misfortune !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Yawning .Not for you , child . Cheer up , I 'll look after him !Exit . Lulu puts her left foot on a foot-stool , fastens her garter , and goes out into the card-room . Then Rodrigo is cuffed in from the dining-room , lower left , by Casti-Piani .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: You can treat me decently anyway !

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: Still perfectly unemotional .Whatever would induce me to do that ? I will know what you said to her here a little while ago .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Then you can be very fond of me !

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: Will you bandy words with me , dog ? You demanded that she go up in the lift with you !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: That 's a shameless , perfidious lie !

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: She told me so herself . You threatened to denounce her if she did n't go with you .— Shall I shoot you on the spot ?

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: The shameless hussy ! As if anything like that could occur to me !— Even if I should want to have her , God knows I do n't first need to threaten her with prison !

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: Thank you . That 's all I wanted to know .Exit , upper left .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Such a hound ! A fellow I could throw up onto the roof so he 'd stick like a Limburger cheese !— Come back here , so I can wind your guts round your neck . That would be even better !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Enters , lower left ; merrily .Where were you ? I 've been hunting for you like a pin .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: I 've shown * him * what it means to start anything with me !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Whom ?

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Your Casti-Piani ! What made you tell him , you slut , that I wanted to seduce you ? !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Did you not ask me to give myself to my deceased husband 's son for twenty thousand in Jungfrau shares ?

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Because it 's your duty to take pity on the poor young fellow ! You shot away his father before his nose in the very best years of life ! But your Casti-Piani will think it over before he comes into my sight again . I gave him one in the basket that made the tripes fly to heaven like Roman candles . If you 've got no better substitute for me , then I 'm sorry ever to have had your favor !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Lady Geschwitz is in the fearfullest case . She twists herself up in fits . She 's at the point of jumping into the water if you let her wait any longer .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: What 's the beast waiting for ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: For you , to take her with you .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Then give her my regards , and she can jump into the water .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: She 'll lend me twenty thousand marks to save me from destruction if you will preserve her from it herself . If you 'll take her off to-night , I 'll deposit twenty thousand marks to-morrow in your name at any bank you say .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: And if I do n't take her off with me ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Denounce me ! Alva and I are dead broke .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Devil and damnation !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: You make four people happy if you do n't take things too exactly and sacrifice yourself for a beneficent purpose .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: That wo n't go ; I know that , beforehand . I 've tried that out enough now . Who counts on an honorable soul like that in a bag o ’ bones ! What the person had for me was her being an aristocrat . My behavior was as gentleman-like , and more , as you could find among German circus-people . If I 'd only just pinched her in the calves once !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Watchfully .She is still a virgin .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Sighing .If there 's a God in heaven , you 'll get paid for your jokes some day ! I prophesy that .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Geschwitz waits . What shall I tell her ?

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: My very best wishes , and I am perverse .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: I will deliver that .

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Wait a sec . Is it certain sure I get twenty thousand marks from her ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Ask herself !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Then tell her I 'm ready . I await her in the dining-room . I must just first look after a barrel of caviare .Exit , left . Lulu opens the rear door and calls in a clear voice “ Martha ! ” Countess Geschwitz enters , closing the door behind her .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Pleased .Dear heart , you can save me from death to-night .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: How ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: By going to a certain house with the acrobat .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: What for , dear ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: He says you must belong to him this very night or he 'll denounce me to-morrow .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: You know I can n't belong to any man . My fate has not permitted that .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: If you do n't please him , that 's his own fix . Why has he fallen in love with you ?

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: But he 'll get as brutal as a hangman . He 'll revenge himself for his disappointment and beat my head in . I 've been thru that already .... Can you not possibly spare me this hardest test ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: What will you gain by his denouncing me ?

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: I have still enough of my fortune to take us to America together in the steerage . There you 'd be safe from all your pursuers .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Pleased and gay .I want to stay here . I can never be happy in any other city . You must tell him that you can n't live without him . Then he 'll feel flattered and be gentle as a lamb . You must pay the coachman , too : give him this paper with the address on it . 376 is a sixth-class hotel where they 're expecting you with him this evening .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: Shuddering .How can such a monstrosity save your life ? I do n't understand that . You have conjured up to torture me the most terrible fate that can fall upon outlawed me !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Watchful .Perhaps the encounter will cure you .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: Sighing .O Lulu , if an eternal retribution does exist , I hope I may not have to answer then for you . I cannot make myself believe that no God watches over us . Yet you are probably right that there is nothing there , for how can an insignificant worm like me have provoked his wrath so as to experience only horror there where all living creation swoons for bliss ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: You need n't complain . When you * are * happy you 're a hundred thousand times happier than one of us ordinary mortals ever is !

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: I know that too ! I envy no one ! But I am still waiting . You have deceived me so often already .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: I am yours , my darling , if you quiet Mr. Acrobat till to-morrow . He only wants his vanity placated . You must beseech him to take pity on you .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: And to-morrow ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: I await you , my heart . I shall not open my eyes till you come : see no chambermaid , receive no hair-dresser , not open my eyes before you are with me .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: Then let him come .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: But you must throw yourself at his head , dear ! Have you got the house-number ?

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: Three-seventy-six . But quick now !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Calls into the dining-room .Ready , my darling ?

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: Entering .The ladies will pardon my mouth 's being full .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: Seizing his hand .I implore you , have mercy on my need !

sp.speaker: RODRIGO
sp.p: A la bonne heure ! Let us mount the scaffold !Offers her his arm .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Good-night , children !Accompanies them into the corridor .... then quickly returns with Bob .Quick , quick , Bob ! We must get away this moment ! You escort me ! But we must change clothes !

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: Curt and clear .As the gracious lady bids .
