sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Oh what , gracious lady ! You give me your clothes and put on mine . Come !Exeunt into the dining-room . Noise in the card-room , the doors are torn open , and Puntschu , Heilmann , Alva , Bianetta , Magelone , Kadidia and Ludmilla enter , Heilmann holding a piece of paper with a glowing Alpine peak at its top .

lg.l: Will you accept this share of
Jungfrau-stock , sir ?

sp.speaker: PUNTSCHU
sp.p: But that paper has no exchange , my friend .

sp.speaker: HEILMANN
sp.p: You rascal ! You just do n't want to give me my revenge !

sp.speaker: MAGELONE
sp.p: To Bianetta .Have you any idea what it 's all about ?

sp.speaker: LUDMILLA
sp.p: Puntschu has taken all his money from him , and now gives up the game .

sp.speaker: HEILMANN
sp.p: Now he 's got cold feet , the filthy Jew !

sp.speaker: PUNTSCHU
sp.p: How have I given up the game ? How have I got cold feet ? The gentleman has merely to lay plain cash ! Is this my banking-office I 'm in ? He can proffer me his trash to-morrow morning !

sp.speaker: HEILMANN
sp.p: Trash you call that ? The stock in my knowledge is at 210 !

sp.speaker: PUNTSCHU
sp.p: Yesterday it was at 210 , you 're right . To-day , it 's just nowhere . And to-morrow you 'll find nothing cheaper or more tasteful to paper your stairs with .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: But how is that possible ? Then we * would * be down and out !

sp.speaker: PUNTSCHU
sp.p: Well , what am I to say , who have lost my whole fortune in it ! To-morrow morning I shall have the pleasure of taking up the struggle for an assured existence for the thirty-sixth time !

lg.l: Am I dreaming or do I really hear the
Jungfrau-stock has fallen ?

sp.speaker: PUNTSCHU
sp.p: Fallen even lower than you ! Tho you can use ‘ em for curl-paper .

sp.speaker: MAGELONE
sp.p: O God in Heaven ! Ten years ’ work !Falls in a faint .

sp.speaker: KADIDIA
sp.p: Wake up , mama ! Wake up !

sp.speaker: BIANETTA
sp.p: Say , Mr. Puntschu , where will you eat this evening , since you 've lost your whole fortune ?

sp.speaker: PUNTSCHU
sp.p: Wherever you like , young lady ! Take me where you will , but quickly ! Here it 's getting frightful .Exeunt Puntschu and Bianetta .

lg.stage: Squeezing up his stock and flinging it to the ground .
lg.l: That is what one gets from this pack !

sp.speaker: LUDMILLA
sp.p: Why do you speculate on the Jungfrau too ? Send a few little notices on the company to the German police here , and then you 'll still win something in the end .

sp.speaker: HEILMANN
sp.p: I 've never tried that in my life , but if you want to help me —?

lg.l: Let 's go to an all-night restaurant . Do you know the
Five-footed Calf ?

sp.speaker: HEILMANN
sp.p: I 'm very sorry —

sp.speaker: LUDMILLA
sp.p: Or the Sucking Lamb , or the Smoking Dog ? They 're all right near here . We 'll be all by ourselves there , and before dawn we 'll have a little article ready .

sp.speaker: HEILMANN
sp.p: Do n't you sleep ?

lg.l: Oh , of course ; but not at night .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Who has been trying to resuscitate Magelone .Ice-cold hands ! Ah , what a splendid woman ! We must undo her waist . Come , Kadidia , undo your mother 's waist ! She 's so fearfully tight-laced .

sp.speaker: KADIDIA
sp.p: Without stirring .I 'm afraid .Lulu enters lower left in a jockey-cap , red jacket , white leather breeches and riding boots , a riding cape over her shoulders .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Have you any cash , Alva ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Looking up .Have you gone crazy ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: In two minutes the police 'll be here . We are denounced . You can stay of course , if you 're eager to !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Springing up .Merciful Heaven !Exeunt Alva and Lulu .

sp.speaker: KADIDIA
sp.p: Shaking her mother , in tears .Mama , Mama ! Wake up ! They 've all run away !

sp.speaker: MAGELONE
sp.p: Coming to herself .And youth gone ! And my best days gone ! Oh , this life !

sp.speaker: KADIDIA
sp.p: But I 'm young , mama ! Why should n't I earn any money ? I do n't want to go back to the convent ! Please , mama , keep me with you !

sp.speaker: MAGELONE
sp.p: God bless you , sweetheart ! You do n't know what you say — Oh , no , I shall look around for an engagement in a Variete , and sing the people my misfortunes with the Jungfrau-stock . Things like that are always applauded .

sp.speaker: KADIDIA
sp.p: But you 've got no voice , mama !

sp.speaker: MAGELONE
sp.p: Ah , yes , that 's true !

sp.speaker: KADIDIA
sp.p: Take me with you to the Variete !

sp.speaker: MAGELONE
sp.p: No , it would break my heart !— But , well , if it can n't be otherwise , and you 're so made for it ,— I can n't change things !— Yes , we can go to the Olympia together to-morrow !

sp.speaker: KADIDIA
sp.p: O mama , how glad that makes me feel !A plain-clothes detective enters , upper left .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: In the name of the law — I arrest you !

sp.speaker: CASTI-PIANI
sp.p: Following him , bored .What sort of nonsense is that ? * That * is n't the right one !

div.head: ACT III

stage.stage: An attic room , without windows , but with two sky-lights , under one of which stands a bowl filled with rain-water . Down right , a door thru a board partition into a sort of cubicle under the slanting roof . Near it , a wobbly flower-table with a bottle and a smoking oil-lamp on it . Upper right , a worn-out couch . Door centre ; near it , a chair without a seat . Down left , below the entrance door , a torn gray mattress . None of the doors can shut tight .
The rain beats on the roof . Schigolch in a long gray overcoat lies on the mattress ; Alva on the couch , wrapped in a plaid whose straps still hang on the wall above him .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: The rain 's drumming for the parade .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Cheerful weather for her first appearance ! I dreamt just now we were dining together at Olympia . Bianetta was still with us . The table-cloth was dripping on all four sides with champagne .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Ya , ya . And I was dreaming of a Christmas pudding .Lulu appears , back , barefoot , in a torn black dress , but with her hair falling to her shoulders .Where have you been ? Curling your hair first ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: She only does that to revive old memories .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: If one could only get warmed , just a little , from one of you !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Will you enter barefoot on your pilgrimage ?

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: The first step always costs all kinds of moaning and groaning . Twenty years ago it was no whit better , and what she has learned since then ! The coals only have to be blown . When she 's been at it a week , not ten locomotives will hold her in our miserable attic .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: The bowl is running over .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: What shall I do with the water ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Pour it out the window .Lulu gets up on the chair and empties the bowl thru the sky-light .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: It looks as if the rain would let up at last .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Your wasting the time when the clerks go home after supper .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Would to God I were lying somewhere where no step would wake me any more !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Would I were , too ! Why prolong this life ? Let 's rather starve to death together this very evening in peace and concord ! Is it not the last stage now ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Why do n't * you * go out and get us something to eat ? You 've never earned a penny in your whole life !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: In this weather , when no one would kick a dog from his door ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: But me ! I , with the little blood I have left in my limbs , I am to stop your mouths !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: I do n't touch a farthing of the money !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Let her go , just ! I long for one more Christmas pudding ; then I 've had enough .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: And I long for one more beefsteak and a cigarette ; then die ! I was just dreaming of a cigarette , such as has never yet been smoked !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: She 'll see us put an end to before her eyes , before doing herself a little pleasure .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: The people on the street will sooner leave cloak and coat in my hands than go with me for nothing ! If you had n't sold my clothes , I at least would n't need to be afraid of the lamp-light . I 'd like to see the woman who could earn anything in the rags I 'm wearing on my body !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: I have left nothing human untried . As long as I had money I spent whole nights making up tables with which one could n't help winning against the cleverest card-sharps . And yet evening after evening I lost more than if I had shaken out gold by the pailful . Then I offered my services to the courtesans ; but they do n't take anyone without the stamps of the courts , and they see at the first glance if one 's related to the guillotine or not .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Ya , ya .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: I spared myself no disillusionments ; but when I made jokes , they laughed at * me *, and when I behaved as respectable as I am , they boxed my ears , and when I tried being smutty , they got so chaste and maidenly that my hair stood up on my head for horror . He who has not prevailed over society , they have no confidence in .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Wo n't you kindly put on your boots now , child ? I do n't think I shall grow much older in this lodging . It 's months since I had any feeling in the ends of my toes . Toward midnight , I 'll drink a bit more down in the pub . The lady that keeps it told me yesterday I seemed to really want to be her lover .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: In the name of the three devils , I 'll go down !She puts to her mouth the bottle on the flower-table .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: So they can smell your stink a half-hour off !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: I sha n't drink it all .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: You wo n't go down . You 're my woman . You sha n't go down . I forbid it !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: What would you forbid your woman when you can n't support yourself ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Whose fault is that ? Who but my woman has laid me on the sick-bed ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Am I sick ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Who has trailed me thru the dung ? Who has made me my father 's murderer ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Did * you * shoot him ? He did n't lose much , but when I see you lying there I could hack off both my hands for having sinned so against my judgment !She goes out , into her room .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: She infected me from her Casti-Piani . It 's a long time since she was susceptible to it herself !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Little devils like her can n't begin putting up with it too soon , if angels are ever going to come out of them .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: She ought to have been born Empress of Russia . Then she 'd have been in the right place . A second Catherine the Second !Lulu re-enters with a worn-out pair of boots , and sits on the floor to put them on .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: If only I do n't go headfirst down the stairs ! Ugh , how cold ! Is there anything in the world more dismal than a daughter of joy ?

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Patience , patience ! She 's only got to take the right road into the business at the start .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: It 's all right with me ! Nothing 's wrong with me any more .Puts the bottle to her lips .That warms one ! O accursed !Exit .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: When we hear her coming , we must creep into my cubby-hole awhile .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: I 'm damned sorry for her ! When I think back .... I grew up with her in a way , you know .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: She 'll hold out as long as I live , anyway .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: We treated each other at first like brother and sister . Mama was still living then . I met her by chance one morning when she was dressing . Dr. Goll had been called for a consultation . Her hair-dresser had read my first poem , that I 'd had printed in “ Society ": “ Follow thy pack far over the mountains ; it will return again , covered with sweat and dust — ”

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Oh , ya !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: And then she came , in rose-colored muslin , with nothing under it but a white satin slip — for the Spanish ambassador 's ball . Dr. Goll seemed to feel his death near . He asked me to dance with her , so she should n't cause any mad acts . Papa meanwhile never turned his eyes from us , and all thru the waltz she was looking over my shoulder , only at him .... Afterwards she shot him . It is unbelievable .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: I 've only got a very strong doubt whether anyone will bite any more .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: I should n't like to advise it to anybody !Schigolch grunts .At that time , tho she was a fully developed woman , she had the expression of a five-year-old , joyous , utterly healthy child . And she was only three years younger than me then — but how long ago it is now ! For all her immense superiority in matters of practical life , she let me explain “ Tristan and Isolde ” to her — and how entrancingly she could listen ! Out of the little sister who at her marriage still felt like a school-girl , came the unhappy , hysterical artist 's wife . Out of the artist 's wife came then the spouse of my blessed father , and out of * her * came , then , my mistress . Well , so that is the way of the world . Who will prevail against it ?

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: If only she does n't skid away from the gentlemen with honorable intentions and bring us up instead some vagabond she 's exchanged her heart 's secrets with .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: I kissed her for the first time in her rustling bridal dress . But afterwards she did n't remember it .... All the same , I believe she had thought of me even in my father 's arms . It can n't have been often with him : he had his best time behind him , and she deceived him with coachman and boot-black ; but when she did give herself to him , then I stood before her soul . Thru that , too , without my realizing it , she attained this dreadful power over me .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: There they are !Heavy steps are heard mounting the stairs .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Starting up .I will not endure it ! I 'll throw the fellow out !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Wearily picks himself up , takes Alva by the collar and cuffs him toward the left .Forward , forward ! How is the young man to confess his trouble to her with us two sprawling round here ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: But if he demands other things — low things — of her ?

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: If , well , if ! What more will he demand of her ? He 's only a man like the rest of us !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: We must leave the door open .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Pushing Alva in , right .Nonsense ! Lie down !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: I 'll hear it soon enough . Heaven spare him !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Closing the door , from inside .Shut up !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Faintly .He 'd better look out !Lulu enters , followed by Hunidei , a gigantic figure with a smooth-shaven , rosy face , sky-blue eyes , and a friendly smile . He wears a tall hat and overcoat and carries a dripping umbrella .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Here 's where I live .Hunidei puts his finger to his lips and looks at Lulu significantly . Then he opens his umbrella and puts it on the floor , rear , to dry .Of course , I know it is n't very comfortable here .Hunidei comes forward and puts his hand over her mouth .What do you mean me to understand by that ?Hunidei puts his hand over her mouth , and his finger to his lips .I do n't know what that means .Hunidei quickly stops her mouth . Lulu frees herself .We 're quite alone here . No one will hear us .Hunidei lays his finger on his lips , shakes his head , points at Lulu , opens his mouth as if to speak , points at himself and then at the door .Herr Gott , he 's a monster !Hunidei stops her mouth ; then goes rear , folds up his overcoat and lays it over the chair near the door ; then comes down with a broad smile , takes Lulu 's head in both his hands and kisses her on the forehead . The door , right , half opens .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Behind the door .He 's got a screw loose .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: He 'd better look out !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: She could n't have brought up anything drearier !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Stepping back .I hope you 're going to give me something !Hunidei stops her mouth and presses a gold-piece in her hand , then looks at her uncertain , questioningly , as she examines it and throws it from one hand to the other .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: All right , it 's good .Puts it into her pocket . Hunidei quickly stops her mouth , gives her a few silver coins , and glances at her commandingly .Oh , that 's nice of you !Hunidei leaps madly about the room , brandishing his arms and staring upward in despair . Lulu cautiously nears him , throws an arm round him and kisses him on the mouth . Laughing soundlessly , he frees himself from her and looks questioningly . She takes up the lamp and opens the door to her room . He goes in smiling , taking off his hat . The stage is dark save for what light comes thru the cracks of the door . Alva and Schigolch creep out on all fours .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: They 're gone .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Behind him .Wait .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: One can hear nothing here .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: You 've heard that often enough !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: I will kneel before her door .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Little mother 's sonny !Presses past Alva , gropes across the stage to Hunidei 's coat , and searches the pockets . Alva crawls to Lulu 's door .Gloves , nothing more !Turns the coat round , searches the inside pockets , pulls a book out that he gives to Alva .Just see what that is .Alva holds the book to the light .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Wearily deciphering the title-page .Warnings to pious pilgrims and such as wish to be so . Very helpful . Price , 2 s. 6 d .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: It looks to me as if God had left * him * pretty completely .Lays the coat over the chair again and makes for the cubby-hole .There 's nothing doing with these people . The country 's best time 's behind it !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Life is never as bad as it 's painted .He , too , creeps back .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Not even a silk muffler he 's got and yet in Germany we creep on our bellies before this rabble .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Come , let 's vanish again .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: She only thinks of herself , and takes the first man that runs across her path . Hope the dog remembers her the rest of his life !They disappear , left , shutting the door behind them . Lulu re-enters , setting the lamp on the table . Hunidei follows .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Will you come to see me again ?Hunidei stops her mouth . She looks upward in a sort of despair and shakes her head . Hunidei , putting his coat on , approaches her grinning ; she throws her arms around his neck ; he gently frees himself , kisses her hand , and turns to the door . She starts to accompany him , but he signs to her to stay behind and noiselessly leaves the room . Schigolch and Alva re-enter .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Tonelessly .How he has stirred me up !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: How much did he give you ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: As before .Here it is ! All ! Take it ! I 'm going down again .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: We can still live like princes up here .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: He 's coming back .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Then let 's just retire again , quick .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: He 's after his prayer-book . Here it is . It must have fallen out of his coat .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Listening .No , that is n't he . That 's some one else .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Some one 's coming up . I hear it quite plainly .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Now there 's some one tapping at the door . Who may that be ?

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Probably a good friend he 's recommended us to . Come in !Countess Geschwitz enters , in poor clothes , with a canvas roll in her hand .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: To Lulu .If I 've come at a bad time , I 'll turn around again . The truth is , I have n't spoken to a living soul for ten days . I must just tell you right off , I have n't got any money . My brother never answered me at all .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Your ladyship would now like to stretch her feet out under our table ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Tonelessly .I 'm going down again .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: Where are you going in this pomp ?— However , I come not wholly empty-handed . I bring you something else . On my way here an old-clothes man offered me twelve shillings for it , but I could not force myself to part from it . You can sell it , though , if you want to .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: What is it ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Let us see it .Takes the canvas and unrolls it . Visibly rejoiced .Oh , by God , it 's Lulu 's portrait !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Screaming .Monster , you brought that here ? Get it out of my sight ! Throw it out of the window !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Suddenly with renewed life , deeply pleased .Why , I should like to know ? Looking on this picture I regain my self-respect . It makes my fate comprehensible to me . Everything we have endured gets clear as day .In a somewhat elegiac strain .Let him who feels secure in his middle-class position when he sees these blossoming pouting lips , these child-eyes , big and innocent , this rose-white body abounding in life ,— let him cast the first stone at us !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: We must nail it up . It will make an excellent impression on our patrons .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Energetic .There 's a nail sticking all ready for it in the wall .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: But how did you come upon this acquisition ?

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: I secretly cut it out of the wall in your house , there , after you were gone .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Too bad the color 's got rubbed off round the edges . You did n't roll it up carefully enough .Fastens it to a high nail in the wall .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: It 's got to have another one underneath if it 's going to hold . It makes the whole flat look more elegant .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Let me alone ; I know how I 'll do it .He tears several nails out of the wall , pulls off his left boot , and with its heel nails the edges of the picture to the wall .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: It 's just got to hang a while again , to get its proper effect . Whoever looks at that 'll imagine afterwards he 's been in an Indian harem .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Putting on his boot again , standing up proudly .Her body was at its highest point of development when that picture was painted . The lamp , kid dear ! Seems to me it 's got extraordinarily dark .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: He must have been an eminently gifted artist who painted that !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Perfectly composed again , stepping before the picture with the lamp .Did n't you know him , then ?

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: No . It must have been long before my time . I only occasionally heard chance remarks of yours , that he had cut his throat from persecution-mania .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Comparing the picture with Lulu .The child-like expression in the eyes is still absolutely the same in spite of all she has lived thru since .In joyous excitement .The dewy freshness that covered her skin , the sweet-smelling breath from her lips , the rays of light that beam from her white forehead , and this challenging splendor of young flesh in throat and arms —

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: All that 's gone with the rubbish wagon . She can say with self-assurance : That was me once ! The man she falls into the hands of to-day ‘ ll have no conception of what we were when we were young .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Cheerfully .God be thanked , we do n't notice the continual decline when we see a person all the time .Lightly .The woman blooms for us in the moment when she hurls the man to destruction for the rest of his life . That is her nature and her destiny .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Down in the street-lamp 's shimmer she 's still a match for a dozen walking spectres . The man who still wants to make connections at this hour looks out more for heart-qualities than mere physical good points . He decides for the pair of eyes from which the least thievery sparkles .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Now as pleased as Alva .I shall see if you 're right . Adieu .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: In sudden anger .You shall not go down again , as I live !

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: Where do you want to go ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Down to fetch up a man .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: Lulu !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: She 's done it once to-day already .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: Lulu , Lulu , where you go I go too .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: If you want to put your bones up for sale , kindly get a district of your own !

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: Lulu , I shall not stir from your side ! I have weapons upon me .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Confound it all , her ladyship plots to fish with our bait !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: You 're killing me . I can n't stand it here any more .Exit .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: You need fear nothing . I am with you .Follows her .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Whimpering , throws himself on his couch . Schigolch swears , loudly and grumbling .I guess there 's not much more good to expect on this side !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: We ought to have held the creature back by the throat . She 'll scare away everything that breathes with her aristocratic death 's head .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: She 's flung me onto a sick-bed and larded me with thorns outside and in !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: And she 's still got enough strength in her body to do the same for ten men alright .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: No mortally wounded man 'll ever find the stab of mercy welcomer than I !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: If she had n't enticed the acrobat to my place that time , we 'd have him round our necks to-day too .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: I see it swinging above my head as Tantalus saw the branch with the golden apples !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: On his mattress .Wo n't you turn up the lamp a little ?

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: Can a simple , natural man in the wilderness suffer so unspeakably ? !— God , God , what have I made of my life !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: What 's the beastly weather made of my ulster ! When I was five-and-twenty , I knew how to help myself !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: It has not cost everyone my sunny , glorious youth !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: I guess it 'll go out in a minute . Till they come back it 'll be as dark in here again as in mother 's womb .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: With the clearest consciousness of my purpose I sought intercourse with people who 'd never read a book in their lives . With self-denial , with exaltation , I clung to the elements , that I might be carried to the loftiest heights of poetic fame . The reckoning was false . I am the martyr of my calling . Since the death of my father I have not written a single line !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: If only they have n't stayed together ! Nobody but a silly boy will go with two , no matter what .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: They 've not stayed together !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: That 's what I hope . If need be , she 'll keep the creature off from her with kicks .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: One , risen from the dregs , is the most celebrated man of his nation ; another , born in the purple , lies in the mud and cannot die !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Here they come !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: And what blessed hours of mutual joy in creation they had lived thru with each other !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: They can do that now , for the first time rightly .— We must hide again .

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: I stay here .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Just what do you pity them for ?— Who spends his money has his good reasons for it !

sp.speaker: ALVA
sp.p: I have no longer the moral courage to let my comfort be disturbed for a miserable sum of money !He wraps himself up in his plaid .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: Noblesse oblige ! A respectable man does what he owes his position .He hides , left . Lulu opens the door , saying “ Come right in , dearie , ” and there enters Prince Kungu Poti , heir-apparent of Uahubee , in a light suit , white spats , tan button-boots , and a gray tall hat . His speech , interrupted with frequent hiccoughs , abounds with the peculiar African hiss-sounds .

sp.speaker: KUNGU POTI
sp.p: God damn — it 's dark on the stairs !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: It 's lighter here , sweetheart .Pulling him forward by the hand .Come on !

sp.speaker: KUNGU POTI
sp.p: But it 's cold here , awful cold !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Have some brandy ?

sp.speaker: KUNGU POTI
sp.p: Brandy ? You bet — always ! Brandy 's good !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Giving him the bottle .I do n't know where there 's a glass .

sp.speaker: KUNGU POTI
sp.p: Does n't matter .Drinks .Brandy ! Lots of it !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: You 're a nice-looking young man .

sp.speaker: KUNGU POTI
sp.p: My father 's the emperor of Uahubee . I 've got six wives here , two Spanish , two English , two French . Well — I do n't like my wives . Always I must take a bath , take a bath , take a bath ....

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: How much will you give me ?

sp.speaker: KUNGU POTI
sp.p: Gold ! Trust me , you shall have gold ! One gold-piece . I always give gold-pieces .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: You can give it to me later , but show it to me .

sp.speaker: KUNGU POTI
sp.p: I never pay beforehand .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: But you can show it to me , thoh !

lg.l: Do n't understand , do n't understand ! Come ,
Ragapsishimulara !
Come on !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Defending herself with all her strength .Let me be ! Let me be !Alva , who has risen painfully from his couch , sneaks up to Kungu Poti from behind and pulls him back by the collar .

sp.speaker: KUNGU POTI
sp.p: Whirling round .Oh ! Oh ! This is a murder-hole ! Come , my friend , I 'll put you to sleep !Strikes him over the head with a loaded cane . Alva groans and falls in a heap .Here 's a sleeping-draught ! Here 's opium for you ! Sweet dreams to you ! Sweet dreams !Then he gives Lulu a kiss ; pointing to Alva .He dreams of you , Ragapsishimulara ! Sweet dreams !Rushing to the door .Here 's the door ! !Exit .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: But I 'll not stay here ? !— Who can stand it here now !— Rather down onto the street !Exit . Schigolch comes out .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: — Blood !— Alva !— He 's got to be put away somewhere . Hop !— Or else our friends ‘ ll get a shock from him — Alva ! Alva !— He that is n't quite clear about it —! One thing or t'other ; or it 'll soon be too late ! I 'll give him legs !Strikes a match and sticks it into Alva 's collar ....He will have his rest . But no one sleeps here .—Drags him by the head into Lulu 's room . Returning , he tries to turn up the light .It 'll be time for me , too , right soon now , or they 'll get no more Christmas puddings down there in the tavern . God knows when she 'll be coming back from her pleasure tour !Fixing an eye on Lulu 's picture .She does n't understand business ! She can n't live off love , because her life is love .— There she comes . I 'll just talk straight to her once —Countess Geschwitz enters .If you want to lodge with us to-night , kindly take a little care that nothing is stolen here .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: How dark it is here !

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: It gets much darker than this .— The doctor 's already gone to rest .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: She sent me ahead .

sp.speaker: SCHIGOLCH
sp.p: That was sensible .— If anyone asks for me , I 'm sitting downstairs in the pub .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: After he has gone .I will sit behind the door . I will look on at everything and not quiver an eye-lash .Sits on the broken chair .Men and women do n't know themselves — they know not what they are . Only one who is neither man nor woman knows them . Every word they say is untrue , a lie . And they do not know it , for they are to-day so and to-morrow so , according as they have eaten , drunk , and loved , or not . Only the body remains for a time what it is , and only the children have reason . The men and women are like the animals : none knows what it does . When they are happiest they bewail themselves and groan , and in their deepest misery they rejoice over every tiny morsel . It is strange how hunger takes from men and women the strength to withstand misfortune . But when they have fed full they make this world a torture-chamber , they throw away their lives to satisfy a whim , a mood . Have there ever once been men and women to whom love brought happiness ? And what is their happiness , save that they sleep better and can forget it all ? My God , I thank thee that thou hast not made me as these . I am not man nor woman . My body has nothing common with their bodies . Have I a human soul ? Tortured humanity has a little narrow heart ; but I know I deserve nothing when I resign all , sacrifice all ....Lulu opens the door , and Dr. Hilti enters . Geschwitz , unnoticed , remains motionless by the door .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Gaily .Come right in ! Come !— you 'll stay with me all night ?

sp.speaker: DR. HILTI
sp.p: His accent is very broad and flat .But I have no more than five shillings on me . I never take more than that when I go out .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: That 's enough , because it 's you ! You have such faithful eyes ! Come , give me a kiss !Dr. Hilti begins to swear , in the broadest north-country vowels .Please , do n't say that .

sp.speaker: DR. HILTI
sp.p: By the de'il , ‘ tis the first time I 've e'er gone with a girrl ! You can believe me . Mass , I had n't thought it would be like this !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Are you married ?

sp.speaker: DR. HILTI
sp.p: Heaven and Hail , why do you think I am married ?— No , I 'm a tutor ; I read philosophy at the University . The truth is , I come of a very old country family . As a student , I got just two shillings pocket-money , and I could make better use of that than for girrls !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: So you have never been with a woman ?

sp.speaker: DR. HILTI
sp.p: Just so , yes ! But I want it now . I got engaged this evening to a country-woman of mine . She 's a governess here .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Is she pretty ?

sp.speaker: DR. HILTI
sp.p: Yaw , she 's got a hundred thousand .— I am very eager , as it seems to me ....

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Tossing back her hair .I * am * in luck !Takes the lamp .Well , if you please , Mr. Tutor ?They go into her room . Geschwitz draws a small black revolver from her pocket and sets it to her forehead .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: — Come , come ,— beloved !Dr. Hilti tears open the door again .—

sp.speaker: DR. HILTI
sp.p: Plunging in .Insane seraphs ! Some one 's lying in there !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Lamp in hand , holds him by the sleeve .Stay with me !

sp.speaker: DR. HILTI
sp.p: A dead man ! A corpse !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Stay with me ! Stay with me !

sp.speaker: DR. HILTI
sp.p: Tearing away .A corpse is lying in there ! Horrors ! Hail ! Heaven !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Stay with me !

sp.speaker: DR. HILTI
sp.p: Where d 's it go out ?Sees Geschwitz .And there is the devil !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Please , stop , stay !

sp.speaker: DR. HILTI
sp.p: Devil , devilled devilry !— Oh , thou eternal —Exit .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Rushing after him .Stop ! Stop !

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: Alone , lets the revolver sink .Better , hang ! If she sees me lie in my blood to-day she 'll not weep a tear for me ! I have always been to her but the docile tool that could be used for the heaviest labor . From the first day she has abhorred me from the depths of her soul .— Shall I not rather jump from the bridge ? Which could be colder , the water or her heart ? I would dream till I was drowned .— Better , hang !— — Stab ?— Hm , there would be no use in that — — How often have I dreamt that she kissed me ! But a minute more ; an owl knocks there at the window , and I wake up .— — Better , hang ! Not water ; water is too clean for me .Starting up .There !— There ! There it is !— Quick now , before she comes !Takes the plaid-straps from the wall , climbs on the chair , fastens them to a hook in the door-post , puts her head thru them , kicks the chair away , and falls to the ground .Accursed life !— Accursed life !— Could it be before me still ? ?— Let me speak just once to thy heart , my angel ! But thou art cold !— I am not to go yet ! Perhaps I am even to have been happy once .— Listen to him , Lulu ! I am not to go yet !She drags herself before Lulu 's picture , sinks to her knees and folds her hands .My adored angel ! My love ! My star !— Have mercy upon me , pity me , pity me , pity me !

div.stage: Lulu opens the door , and Jack enters — a thick-set man of elastic movements , with a pale face , inflamed eyes , arched and heavy brows , a drooping mustache , thin imperial and shaggy whiskers , and fiery red hands with gnawed nails . His eyes are fixed on the ground . He wears a dark overcoat and a little round felt hat . Entering , he notices Geschwitz .

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Who is that ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: That 's my sister . She 's crazy . I do n't know how to get rid of her .

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Your mouth looks beautiful .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: It 's my mother 's .

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Looks like it . How much do you want ? I have n't got much money .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Wo n't you spend the night with me here ?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: No , have n't got the time . I must get home .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: You can tell them at home to-morrow that you missed the last ‘ bus and spent the night with a friend .

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: How much do you want ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: I 'm not after lumps of gold , but , well , a little something .

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Turning .Good night ! Good night !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Holds him back .No , no ! Stay , for God 's sake !

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Goes past Geschwitz and opens the cubicle .Why should I stay here till morning ? Sounds suspicious ! When I 'm asleep they 'll turn my pockets out .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: No , I wo n't do that ! No one will ! Do n't go away again for that ! I beg you !

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: How much do you want ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Then give me the half of what I said !

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: No , that 's too much . You do n't seem to have been at this long ?

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: To-day is the first time .She jerks back Geschwitz , on her knees still , half turned toward Jack , by the straps around her neck .Lie down and be quiet !

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Let her alone ! She is n't your sister . She is in love with you .Strokes Geschwitz 's head like a dog 's .Poor beast !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Why do you stare at me so all at once ?

lg.l: I got your measure by the way you walked . I said to myself :
That girl must have a well-built body .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: How can you see things like that ?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: I even saw that you had a pretty mouth . But I 've only got a florin on me .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Well , what difference does that make ! Just give that to me !

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: But you 'll have to give me half back , so I can take the ‘ bus to-morrow morning .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: I have nothing on me .

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Just look , thoh . Hunt thru your pockets !— Well , what 's that ? Let 's see it !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Showing him .That 's all I have .

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Give it to me !

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: I 'll change it to-morrow , and then give you half .

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: No , give it all to me .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Giving it .In God 's name ! But now you come !Takes up the lamp .

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: We need no light . The moon 's out .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Puts the lamp down .As you say .She falls on his neck .I wo n't harm you at all ! I love you so ! Do n't let me beg you any longer !

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Alright ; I 'm with you .Follows her into the cubby-hole . The lamp goes out . On the floor under the two sky-lights appear two vivid squares of moonlight . Everything in the room is clearly seen .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: As in a dream .This is the last evening I shall spend with these people . I 'm going back to Germany . My mother 'll send me the money . I 'll go to a university . I must fight for woman 's rights ; study law ....Lulu shrieks , and tears open the door .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Barefoot , in chemise and petticoat , holding the door shut behind her .Help !

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: Rushes to the door , draws her revolver , and pushing Lulu aside , aims it at the door . As Lulu again cries “ Help ! ”Let go !Jack , bent double , tears open the door from inside , and runs a knife into Geschwitz 's body . She fires one shot , at the roof , and falls with suppressed crying , crumpling up . Jack tears her revolver from her and throws himself against the exit-door .

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: God damn ! I never saw a prettier mouth !Sweat drips from his hairy face . His hands are bloody . He pants , gasping violently , and stares at the floor with eyes popping out of his head . Lulu , trembling in every limb , looks wildly round . Suddenly she seizes the bottle , smashes it on the table , and with the broken neck in her hand rushes upon Jack . He swings up his right foot and throws her onto her back . Then he lifts her up .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: No , no !— Mercy !— Murder !— Police ! Police !

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Be still . You 'll never get away from me again .Carries her in .

sp.speaker: LULU
sp.p: Within , right .No !— No !— No !— — Ah !— Ah !...

div.stage: After a pause , Jack re-enters . He puts the bowl on the table .

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: That * was * a piece of work !Washing his hands .I * am * a damned lucky chap !Looks round for a towel .Not even a towel , these folks here ! Hell of a wretched hole !He dries his hands on Geschwitz 's petticoat .This invert is safe enough from me !To her .It 'll soon be all up with you , too .Exit .

sp.speaker: GESCHWITZ
sp.p: Alone .Lulu !— My angel !— Let me see thee once more ! I am near thee — stay near thee — forever !Her elbows give way .O cursed —! !Dies .
